choices.C: Provides direct access to VDP configuration integrated into the vSphere Client.
choices.A: Provides support for guest-level backups and restores of Microsoft SQL Servers, Exchange Servers, and Share Point Servers.
choices.D: Reduces disk space consumed by virtual machine data using deduplication.
choices.B: Provides support for advanced storage services including replication, encryption, deduplication, and compression.

questions.question_text: What is a benefit of using VMware Data Protection (VDP)?

choices.B: The VMFS3 kernel module is not loaded.
choices.D: VMFS3 datastores are not compatible with virtual machines created on an ESXi 6.x host.
choices.A: A VMFS3 datastore cannot be created on an ESXi 6.x host.
choices.C: A VMFS3 datastore cannot be mounted on an ESXi 6.x host.

questions.question_text: What condition would prevent an administrator from creating a new VMFS3 datastore on an ESXi 6.x host using the vSphere Web Client?

discussion.content: A, B, and D are absolutely all correct.
A, B and D all seem to be OK, all will allow the host to synchronize with an NTP server.

choices.C: Use the esxcli hardware clock get command in the ESXi Shell.
choices.A: Log in to the VMware Host Client, navigate to Host > Manage > Time & date and click Edit settings.
choices.E: Configure the VMware Tools time synchronization. BE
choices.B: Select the host in the vSphere Web Client, navigate to Configure > System > Time Configuration and click the Edit button.

questions.question_text: How are ports scaled on vSphere Standard Switches (vSS)?

choices.B: Ports on a vSS can only be statically scaled up or down.
choices.D: Ports on a vSS can only be dynamically scaled up.
choices.A: Ports on a vSS can be dynamically scaled up and down.
choices.C: Ports on a vSS can only be dynamically scaled down.
